Idea: 3 types of AI Tik Tok
Copy:
A problem with AI today is that it means different things to different people. 

This framework from Andrej Karpathy helped give me much more clarity ğŸ‘‡ 

Software 1.0 = Rule-based software systems. Humans program computers to solve problems step-by-step. 

Software 2.0 = Computers program themselves by seeing examples (i.e. machine learning) 

Software 3.0 = Repurposing general-purpose ML models for specific use cases (i.e. GenAI + Foundation Models) 

Butâ€¦ whatâ€™s Software 4.0 going to be? ğŸ¤”

Idea: Using polars for the first time
Copy:
I finally found an excuse to try polars (thanks to Ben for showing me the light). 

For the uninitiated, polars is essentially a (much) faster version of pandas. ğŸ»â€â„ï¸ > ğŸ¼ 

After using it for a recent project, here are 3 things I liked about it ğŸ‘‡ 

1) The Syntax 

Most of the syntax is identical to pandas, which made it super easy to use without any tutorials. 
2) The â€œLazyâ€ API This allows you to manipulate dataframes without loading them into memory. 

At the end, you can perform all the operations via the .collect() method. 
3) .scan_parquet() 

Yes, you can import .parquet files in pandas, but when combined with the Lazy API, this allows you to locally work with 10X bigger datasets in polars than pandas

Idea: Communication challenges for data scientist. Promote blog post
Copy:
This is why data scientists donâ€™t get promoted (hint: Itâ€™s not SWE) ğŸ‘‡ 

A universal challenge for data scientists is communicating effectively with non-technical stakeholders. 

This was one of the biggest limiting factors for those seeking advancement when I worked at a larger enterprise. 

Here are 3 Communication tips that helped me get ahead as a data scientist. 

1) Use Storiesâ€”framing communication as 3-part narrative helps it go down easier e.g. status quo, problem, solution. 

2) Use Examplesâ€”examples make abstract ideas concrete. For instance, a 3-part narrative was used in this post. 

3) Use analogiesâ€”analogies help us learn new things by mapping the unfamiliar to the familiar, which is very handy when explaining technical ideas. 

ğŸ‘‰ I share 4 more tips in the blog in a recent article published in Towards Data Science 

Check it out and let me know how youâ€™ve improved your communication skills.

Idea: Sharing blog post on QLoRA
Copy:

The key challenge is that LLMs are (very) computationally expensive e.g. full fine-tuning of a 70B parameter model requires over 1TB of memory!

Idea: Lessons from mentorship call with $100k/mo entrepreneur
Copy:
Last month, I booked my most expensive mentorship call yet at $700/hr ğŸ˜¬ 

While this might sound like a big number, the person on the other side of the call makes $100k/mo as a solo AI entrepreneur. 

Here are my key takeaways from this conversation... 

1) Focus on customer pain points and problems, not your past experience and skills. 

2) Price for the customer's value, not your time. 

3) The bigger the price tag, the longer the copy (i.e. delay the ask) 

4) Get hyper-clear on the customer and their problem, then attract them with free content (on socials) and a lead magnet. 

5) The difference between 10k/mo and 100k/mo is more often business strategy rather than technical expertise. 

Although these points might be Business 101 for some, many technical founders (like me) never learned these basics. 

This is great news because it means I can probably get significant gains from a few simple adjustments. 

Super grateful to Jason Liu for taking the time to share his wisdom with me ğŸ™

Copy:

However, their immense scale can make deploying them in real-world settings a challenge ğŸ˜®â€ğŸ’¨ 

In my latest blog post, I discuss how to mitigate these challenges using model compression.

Idea: 3 ways to make LLMs multimodal and sharing blog post
Copy:
Over the past year, weâ€™ve seen LLMs gain the ability to see (i.e. process images) and hear (i.e. process audio directly), but how does that work under the hood? 

Here are 3 general ways to do that ğŸ‘‡ 

1. LLM + Tools: Augment LLMs with pre-built components 

2. LLM + Adapters: Augment LLMs with multi-modal encoders or decoders, which are aligned via adapter fine-tuning 

3. Unified Models: Expand LLM architecture to fuse modalities at pre-training 

In my latest blog post in Towards Data Science, I discuss these three approaches and share example code for (locally) using LLaMA 3.2 Vision to perform various image-to-text tasks. 

Check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gGcvVk9u

Idea: Explaining multimodal embeddings and sharing blog post
Copy:
Although text and images may look very different to us, to a neural network, these are represented via the same mathematical object, i.e., a vector. 

Therefore, we can image vector spaces where text and images look similar, given they represent the same underlying information. 

This is the key idea behind multimodal embeddings. 

In my latest blog post, I share how we can generate such representations along with two practical use cases for them: 1) 0-shot Image Classification and 2) Image search. 

Check it out here ğŸ‘‡ https://lnkd.in/g-Dvy9dF

Copy:
Last year, I quit my data science job to pursue entrepreneurship full-time. 

My plan was to sell data science services to fund the development of a product that I could launch a business around ğŸš€ 

While this made a lot of sense on paper, pursuing this path over the last 9 months has made me realize thatâ€”this plan was flawed.

Idea: Importance of deploying ML models and a simple way to do it. Share blog post
Copy:
Although it may seem that machine learning is all about training fancy models, in the real world, a model (by itself) does NOT generate value. 

To turn an ML model into an ML solution (i.e., something valuable), we must â€œdeploy it.â€ 

While this can take many different forms, there is a simple 3-step strategy that works well in many situationsâ€¦

Step 1: Create an inference API 

Step 2: Containerize the API 

Step 3: Run the container on a cloud platform 

ğŸ‘‰ In a recent Towards Data Science article, I break down how to implement this 3-step strategy using FastAPI, Docker, and GCP. 

Check it out and let me know what you think ğŸ‘‡

Idea: Lessons from 13 months of entrepreneurship
Copy:
Itâ€™s been 13 months since I had a W2 job... 

During this time, Iâ€™ve realized there are several popular misconceptions about entrepreneurship. 

Here are a few that are top of mind for me right now ğŸ‘‡ 

âŒ "I need funding to build a business." 
âœ… The vast majority of businesses take no outside funding, and <1% take VC. Figuring out how to survive IS the game. 

âŒ "I need an idea that can scale well." 
âœ… â€Do things that donâ€™t scaleâ€ -Paul Graham. Thereâ€™s no point in scaling something no one wants. IF demand exists, then thereâ€™s always a way to scale. 

âŒ "I need to learn web development frameworks to build a SaaS product." 
âœ… â€Build with the tech you knowâ€ -Peiter Levels. The key is speed. You donâ€™t have six months to take a bootcamp. Learn what you need to solve the problem.

Idea: Advice for data people thinking of pursuing entrepreneurship
Copy:
Last year, I passed on a $150k data science promotion to pursue my entrepreneurial dream life. Hereâ€™s my honest advice for data people considering a similar transition ğŸ‘‡ 

1) Start with a side hustle 

Making money as an entrepreneur is very different than getting a paycheck. A side hustle is a great, low-stakes way to develop the necessary skillset. 

The way I got started was through content creation and freelancing. 

2) Learn how to sell 

Data people typically have high-value skills like programming, data analytics, and machine learning. However, having these skills is not sufficient for monetizing them. 

For that, you need to figure out how to sell yourself and your offers. 

3) Shift your mindset from â€œWhat job can I do?â€ to â€œWhat problems can I solve?â€ 

This is one of the biggest mindset shifts Iâ€™ve had to make this past year. 

Focusing on fulfilling a role means you will always need someone's permission to get paid (whether a manager or a client). 

However, when you focus on solving problems, there are very few constraints on how you can generate value, so you can make a living on your terms.

Idea: 3 habits I had to break to become a senior data scientist
Copy:
Here are 3 habits I had to BREAK before becoming a Senior Data Scientist ğŸ‘‡ 

1) Not digging deeper âŒ 

Something that took me too long to learn was the importance of asking â€œwhy?â€ and digging more deeply into a request to find the underlying problem. 

2) Focusing on technologies instead of problems âŒ 

As a technical person, I found it easy to get so caught up in fancy new technologies that the problem we were trying to solve took a back seat. 

3) Seeking sophistication âŒ 

My favorite part of data science is combining techniques in creative ways to solve problems. 

However, this can lead to overly sophisticated solutions that can often be replaced by simpler ones while still capturing the value. 

ğŸ‘‰ Whatâ€™s a key lesson youâ€™ve learned on your journey?

To be an effective data scientist focus on relationships, not technologies.

1) Be curious (about the problem and where the other side is coming from) 

2) Be transparent (about the limits of my skills and knowledge) 

3) Be myself (donâ€™t try to put up a frontâ€”itâ€™s unsustainable)

Idea: Lesson from posting 1 Youtube video a week
Copy:
Last quarter, I did an experiment where I posted 1 YouTube video every week. 

... it did not go as expected ğŸ˜¬ 

My Hypothesisâ€”Since YouTube drives 80% of my inbound traffic (e.g., paid calls, speaking gigs, project opportunities), doubling my video output will double my business. 

The Resultsâ€”Almost every business metric went down e.g. number of paid calls, number of leads, subscribers per month, YT revenue per month ğŸ˜… 

So what happened? 

My (current) guesses: 

- No LLM videos (these are among my most popular) 
- Less time per video diminished quality 
- I spent too much time making content and not enough time talking to clients and other folks working in the space (i.e. I got out of touch) 

Thatâ€™s why this quarter, Iâ€™ll be scaling back my content quantity and focusing more on quality byâ€¦ 

- Lowering my monthly YT video goal to 3 per month 
- Lowering my consultation rates (so I can stay connected with peopleâ€™s needs) 
- Doing more project work as an intellectual break from making videos

Idea: Why entrepreneurs shouldnâ€™t quit, showcasing data and Lindy principle
Copy:
You often hear entrepreneurs say, â€œkeep goingâ€ or â€œjust donâ€™t quitâ€ 

Hereâ€™s (statistically) why this is good advice ğŸ‘‡ 

The 1st plot below shows business survival rates est in 1994 up until 2023 

This demonstrates the low odds of entrepreneurial success, with 50% closing after 5 years. 

However, something interesting happens if we look at this same curve for businesses that have been around for a few years (2nd plot). 

Here, we see the curve incrementally move up the longer a business stays alive. 

In other words, their probability of survival increases the longer they survive ğŸ“ˆ 

For example, although only 50% of new businesses make it to year 5, these odds jump to 57% after just 1 year in business! 

So this is a reminder to all the entrepreneurs out thereâ€¦ keep going. 

Each day you survive, your odds of success go up a little bit ğŸ’ª

Idea: Getting a data science job was hard until I learned these 5 things
Copy:
Getting a Data Science Job was hard until I learned these 5 things ğŸ‘‡ 

1. Adapt your resume to the specific role 

You have about 7 seconds of a hiring manager's attention when reviewing your resume; use it to call out all the skills they listed in the job description. 

2. Do real-world projects 

While toy projects from class or Kaggle are a great way to learn, hiring managers care about real-world impact. 

3. Make a portfolio 

Despite the free no-code tools for making a portfolio website, most people don't make one. That makes this a super easy way to stand out. 

4. Stay out of the weeds (unless they ask) 

This was one of my greatest struggles. When someone asked about a project, I would dive right into the technical details. 

This is the best way to lose someone's attention (even data scientists). 

5. Be yourself (not who you think they want to hire) 

When I interviewed for my full-time data science role, I dove into a rant about my love for optimization. 

Most people get confused and awkward when I discuss such topics, but not the interviewers. They got pumped up... that's when I knew I found my people ğŸ˜ 

What was an unlock for you when applying to data science roles?

Idea: AI wonâ€™t make you richâ€¦ solving problems will
Copy:
AI wonâ€™t make you richâ€¦ solving problems will. 

Over the past year, Iâ€™ve seen a trend of CEOs and founders scrambling to find AI use cases for their businesses. 

While this AI excitement is great for data scientists like me, it is not sufficient for value generation. 

In other words, â€œusing AIâ€ wonâ€™t necessarily move the needle on the things important to businesses. 

For that, one must solve problemsâ€¦ which may not require a chatbot, RAG system, or any state-of-the-art AI model. 

More often than not, using readily available AI assistants (e.g., ChatGPT) and having good data infrastructure will get businesses 80% there.

âŒ Although ChatGPT (and friends) has captured the worldâ€™s imagination regarding AI, the business value of building an "AI chatbot" may not justify the cost. 

Here are 5 better LLM use cases for business ğŸ‘‡ 

1) Structure unstructured dataâ€”format data from inconvenient sources into a structured database

Idea: 10 AI buzzwords explained
Copy:
AI seems to be riddled with buzzwords these days. 

Here are 10 common AI terms every practitioner should know... 

1) RAG = automatically providing relevant context (i.e. docs) to an AI system so it can generate better responses
2) Vector DB = numerical representations of documents which can be used for RAG and search 
3) Fine-tuning = adapting a model to a particular use case through additional training 
4) AI Agent = an AI system that can plan and execute tasks 
5) Evals = tests that score an AI systemâ€™s efficacy 
6) Hallucination = a "made-up" response from an AI that sounds reasonable 
7) Multimodal = data of different formats (e.g. text, images, audio, videos, tables, time series) 
8) Small Language Models = LLMs with ~1B parameters 
9) Quantization = reducing the precision of model parameters to reduce its size 
10) Distillation = using a large model to train a smaller one 

â€”

 What's missing from this list?

Idea: What does a data scientist (actually) do? Share Tik Tok
Copy:
12 years ago, â€œData Scientistâ€ was the sexiest job of the century. 

Today, itâ€™s still an in-demand role, offering cushy salariesâ€¦ 

But what do they actually do? 

In my view, the main job of a data scientist is to answer questions using data. 

This consists of 4 key activities ğŸ‘‡ 

1) Have a question to answerâ€”this typically comes from clients and business stakeholders. 

2) Acquiring the relevant dataâ€”this is the boring yet most important part. 

3) Analyzing dataâ€”once the data are in a usable form, data scientists use tools like Python or R to compute statistics and create data visualizations. 

4) Build modelsâ€”we can use data to construct predictive models to solve problems and support decision-making.

Idea: How Iâ€™d learn AI if I started over today.
Copy:
AI has changed a lot since I started 5 years ago. 

Hereâ€™s how Iâ€™d learn it if I had to start overâ€¦ 

1. Learn Python 

Although some say you donâ€™t need to learn to code anymore, I still think itâ€™s essential for anyone who wants to build custom software solutions. 

2. Build Projects 

The AI space is too massive and evolving too quickly to effectively learn from a textbook. The best approach (IMO) is to start by building projects and learning concepts as needed. 

3. Start with Kaggle/HF Datasets 

While youâ€™ll never find neatly curated data in the real world, I think using resources like Kaggle or Hugging Face is a great starting place for beginners. 

Some libraries worth learning for this initial project are: Pandas (or Polars), matplotlib, and sklearn 

4. Find a real-world project 

After one or two toy projects, itâ€™s time to start working on something more practical. 

The best projects solve a real-world problem. Iâ€™d seek one out by reaching out to businesses or other orgs in my network to see if I could offer them free work. 

5. Use ChatGPT and Cursor 

AI coding assistants have become the norm for programming. Use them to help you learn faster and get you unblocked as needed.

Idea: AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs
Copy:
AI Roadmap for Entrepreneurs ğŸ‘‡
The 5 things you need to know to build your next AI app...
Use AI Tools
Moving fast means you make mistakes faster than your competition and ship something before you run out of runway.
Tools like ChatGPT, Claude, Cursor, etc., are the best way to do that when it comes to learning and building.
Prompt Engineering
Learning how to write effective prompts not only helps you use AI tools better but also allows you to build better LLM systems.
There are a few universal tips you should know (e.g., give details, use structure, give examples), as well as model-specific ones you can find from the particular model provider.
RAG
While prompting alone can take you far, it falls short when your solution relies on specialized or user-specific information.
Having a basic understanding of retrieval (i.e. search) and how you can use it to improve LLM responses is central.
Tool-use & AI agents
We often donâ€™t just want LLMs to process information for us, we want it to solve our problems.
This is where endowing models with the ability to perform actions (through tool use) will help.
Fine-tuning
Some use cases require changing an LLMâ€™s behavior significantly. If prompting and other workarounds are not enough, fine-tuning is a viable option.
Additionally, this allows you to build specialized models for your specific use case, which can come with significant cost savings.
What would you add to this list?

Idea: 10 AI YouTube channels
Copy:
10 AI YouTube channels that will teach you more in 2025 than a 4-year college degree...

1) Andrej Karpathy

Deep yet accessible lectures on deep learning. Lots on LLMs, but also has an introductory course on neural networks.

2) 3Blue1Brown

Beautiful visualizations of abstract mathematical concepts that make the ideas clearer and more intuitive.

3) Lex Fridman

Conversations with top AI researchers and practitioners. Has helped me put the tech in a larger context and give me insight into how top people are thinking about it.

4) Machine Learning Street Talk

Similarly to Lex in that they share conversations with top AI researchers and practitioners, but these conversations tend to be more technical and exclusively focused on ML.

5) StatQuest with Joshua Starmer PhD

Beginner-friendly explainers on basically anything you want to learn about machine learning and statistics.

6) Serrano Academy with Luis Serrano ğŸ‰ 

Accessible explainers spanning machine learning, deep learning, and emerging AI techniques.

7) Jeremy Howard

Deep learning courses and practical videos on building web apps with Python.

8) Hamel Husain

LLM courses spanning RAG, evals, and fine-tuning from seasoned practitioners.

9) Jason Liu

Lectures on RAG from top developers in the space. Plus, tips on freelancing as in AI and ML.

10) Dave Ebbelaar

Practical videos on how to build AI systems that solve real-world problems. Plus, guides for those just getting started.


ğŸ‘‰ 10 feels too short... who am I missing?

Idea: Technical debt slide screenshot from ABB4 session 1
Copy:
Building a software product is easier than ever.

But thereâ€™s a hidden cost to thisâ€¦

Having an LLM code your entire application helps you move fast, but will incur technical debt.

Like financial debt, technical debt involves getting some benefit now (e.g., a finished app) while delaying the cost until later (e.g., learning how it works).

The other extreme is to code your app completely from scratch and only using the Python docs.

If you do this, youâ€™ll understand every nook and cranny of your code base, but it will take you much longer ğŸ˜… 

Therefore, an important skill developers must learn today is understanding how much technical debt to take on for a specific situation.

If speed now is the top priority, then more debt can be good.

If time later is more important, then less debt is better.


ğŸ‘‰ How do you decide how much technical debt to take on?

Idea: Share FLUX.1 fine-tuning blog post
Copy:
I Fine-tuned FLUX.1 on My Face! 

Here's how you can too...

Step 1: Curate Training Images

Gather 10-20 images of yourself in various settings from different angles. Crop these images so that they are 1024x1024 (using Python).

Step 2: Generate Captions

Use a visual language model (e.g. Llava 13B) to write captions for each photo automatically. Be sure to include a unique "trigger token" in each caption, which the model can learn to associate with your face.

Step 3: Fine-tune the Model

Upload a .zip file containing your image-caption pairs to thisÂ training endpointÂ via the Replicate API (or the web UI).

Step 4: Use the Model

After ~10 min and ~$1 for training, a model playground will spin up on Replicate, from which you can generate images from the model.

I walk through this whole process in a recent blog post.

ğŸ”— Check it out: https://lnkd.in/giYp7VFx

Here are some of my favorites ğŸ‘‡

Idea: Corporate vs Freelance Data Science
Copy:
Corporate vs Freelance Data Scienceâ€¦ My Honest Reflections.

As someone who has worked as a data scientist at a company and independently, here is how Iâ€™d compare the two.

Income ğŸ’¸ 

While the average income is probably about the same, the key difference is the income distribution. 

Corporate salaries are more normally distributed, while freelance income is more fat-tailed. In other words, you can make 2X your corporate salary as an independent, but also you can make 1/2 of it.

Freedom ğŸ¦… 

Freelancing has a corporate beat on this one. 

As a freelancer, you have complete control over what projects you take on and when/where you work.

Uncertainty ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’« 

Broadly speaking, corporate has freelancing beat on this one (especially in the early days). However, thereâ€™s a nuance here. 

Corporate gives a strong perception of stability, so when something eventually DOES go wrong, it can be devastating. 

While for freelance, instability is the norm, so freelancers become much more resilient toward it.

Learning ğŸ¤“ 

Both settings have great learning opportunities. In my experience, however, these have different flavors. 

In corporate, learning can be optional given the coverage of other team members and lean more toward technical skills. 

On the other hand, freelance can be very much â€learn or die,â€ which makes it more powerful, IMO.


How do you compare these two work environments?

Idea: Project share: resume optimizer
Copy:
By the end of this post, youâ€™ll be able to build an AI-powered resume optimization tool (in 6 steps) ğŸ”¨

Step 1: Create a markdown version of your resume with the desired format of your final resume (Note: ChatGPT can do this for you).

Step 2: Read your markdown resume and job description into Python

Step 3: Craft a prompt that combines your resume, the job description, and instructions for creating a new resume in Markdown. 

Step 4: Use OpenAIâ€™s Python API to prompt GPT-4o-mini to rewrite your resume.

Step 5: Convert the markdown output to HTML and then to PDF with the markdown and weasyprint libraries, respectively.

Step 6: Create a simple web UI to make it easy to upload new resumes and optimize them for new JDs

I've implemented this tool and shared the code for free on GitHub.

Here's the link: https://lnkd.in/gw6wNKcn

Idea: My Journey from 0 to 70k Followers
Copy:
My Journey from 0 to 70k Followers

There wasÂ never a master planÂ with my content creation...

I did it mainly because 1)Â it gave me a way to structure my learning andÂ 2)Â it helped me to improve my communication (which was desperately needed ğŸ˜…)

However, today, content creation is the main way I get customers and allows me to work for myself.

Hereâ€™s a recap of my journey (so far):
- Nov 2020: I post my first blog and YouTube video
- Jul 2021: I made my first $1 online (via Mediumâ€™s Partnerâ€™s Program)
- Oct 2021: I had my first $100 month
- May 2022: I graduated with my PhD and accepted a full-time data science role at Toyota
- Dec 2022: I hit 1,000 subs on YouTube
- Jul 2023: I joined YouTubeâ€™s Partnerâ€™s Program and quit my job (which were only loosely correlated)
- Jul 2024: I hit 10,000 subs on YouTube
- Feb 2025: I hit 50,000 subs on YouTube
- Today: I have over 70k followers across Medium and YouTube, which serve as my main lead source for my AI cohort.

While itâ€™s easy to get enchanted by numbers and success stories, itâ€™s important to remember it took me 4.5 years to get to this point (and most of my growth happened in just the last year).

So, if youâ€™re still in the early days, keep going!

Consistency and time are the only things between you and your dream outcome ğŸ¤©

Idea: Employee to entrepreneur mindset shift
Copy:
In my first 12 months of entrepreneurship, I made 1/5th of my full-time salary.

But that all changed when I made this simple mindset shift.

When I quit my job to become an entrepreneur, I asked myself:

"What work can I do to make a living?â€

Looking back, I realize this was the WRONG question. Instead, I should have asked: 

â€œWhat problems can I solve?â€

While the difference may seem subtle, these are fundamentally different mindsets.

The first question is what I call the â€œemployee mindset,â€ which focuses on the inputs you do that eventually generate value.

The second is what I call the â€œentrepreneur mindset,â€ which focuses on the outcomes you want to create for your customer.

In my first year of entrepreneurship, I had an employeeâ€™s mindset, which resulted in me working very, very hard just to make a fraction of my full-time income (basically minimum wage) ğŸ˜… 

It wasnâ€™t until I adopted an â€œentrepreneur mindsetâ€ that I could match my full-time salary.

So, if you are a new or aspiring entrepreneur, ask yourselfâ€¦

Am I focused more on doing a job or solving a specific pain point?
